snippet: With flags at half-staff and businesses shuttered, Pakistanis seemed to be trapped between grief, anger and frustration, for once overcoming their divisions to unite in pain.
abstract: Pakistan, country grown accustomed to attacks by Taliban militants, is thrown into state of horrified paralysis by eight-hour rampage in Peshwar school that killed 148 people, at least 132 of them children; citizens' differences are forgotten momentarily as Peshwar becomes a city of small coffins.

byline.contributor: Ihsanullah Tipu Mehsud contributed reporting from Peshawar, and Declan Walsh from London.

lead_paragraph: With flags at half-staff and businesses shuttered, Pakistanis seemed to be trapped between grief, anger and frustration, for once overcoming their divisions to unite in pain.

headline.main: Horror Paralyzes Pakistan After a Methodical Slaughter
headline.print_headline: Horror Paralyzes Pakistan After a Methodical Slaughter
